evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: the location of a computer rarely allows for definite conclusions regarding the identity of the individual operating the machine
evidence_list.paraphrase: Locating an attacking computer usually does not suffice to identify the individual operator.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Emphasises the 'human–machine gap' that undermines device-to-person attribution, a critical technical limitation with direct legal consequences for proving State responsibility.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 1. Introduction + ## 2. Cyber Security and the Military Paradigm: Self-Defence
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: it took their analysts several years to come up with conclusions that they themselves considered sufficiently convincing to be published.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The authors note that attribution work (e.g. Mandiant) took analysts years before conclusions were deemed publishable.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Concrete example of the time lag for persuasive attribution claims; demonstrates practical difficulties for immediate self-defence responses. Single case evidence — illustrative not systematic.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 1. Introduction + ## 2. Cyber Security and the Military Paradigm: Self-Defence
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: the requirement of immediacy for self-defence to be permitted, meaning the period of time ‘following the execution of an armed attack within which the victim State may reasonably respond in self-defence’, with one relevant factor inter alia being 'the period necessary to identify the attacker'.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The Tallinn Manual frames 'immediacy' as a temporal condition for lawful self-defence and lists the time needed to identify the attacker as a relevant factor.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Shows how temporal legal requirements interact with attribution timelines; Tallinn Manual is influential but non‑binding, so its criteria are interpretive rather than authoritative state practice.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 1. Introduction + ## 2. Cyber Security and the Military Paradigm: Self-Defence
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: In cases where 'the initiator of the attack is not identified until well after the attack' the criterion of immediacy will usually not be met.
evidence_list.paraphrase: If the initiator is identified only well after the attack, the immediacy requirement for lawful self-defence will typically not be satisfied.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Links delayed attribution directly to loss of legal justification for self-defence; critical for RQs on timing and legal permissibility of responses.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 1. Introduction + ## 2. Cyber Security and the Military Paradigm: Self-Defence
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: the State 'may treat those operations as a “cyber campaign” and continue to act in self-defence'.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The Tallinn Manual suggests a State may treat successive cyber operations as a 'cyber campaign' and continue self-defence measures.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Identifies a doctrinal device that can extend the temporal window for self-defence by aggregating incidents; authors warn this risks extending licence to use force and escalation.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 1. Introduction + ## 2. Cyber Security and the Military Paradigm: Self-Defence
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: In particular within the cyber context, the issue of uncertain attribution together with a softening of the immediacy requirement could critically raise the danger of escalation of inter-State conflict.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The authors warn that uncertain attribution combined with softened immediacy could significantly increase the risk of interstate escalation.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Frames the primary policy risk of relaxing attribution/immediacy constraints; important for normative RQs about costs of legal adaptation. Empirical magnitude of escalation is not assessed here.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 1. Introduction + ## 2. Cyber Security and the Military Paradigm: Self-Defence
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: The suggestion that the standards of attribution should shift from 'effective control' to 'overall control' does not touch upon the issue of identification.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The authors argue that moving the attribution test from 'effective control' to 'overall control' would not address the core problem of identifying the human actor.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Dismisses reform proposals focused on control doctrines as irrelevant to the identification problem; useful for evaluating proposals that target doctrinal tweaks rather than evidentiary or technical solutions.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 1. Introduction + ## 2. Cyber Security and the Military Paradigm: Self-Defence
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: the requirement of adequate attribution of an attack before resorting to self-defence measures is 'a luxury unavailable in the cyber attack era'
evidence_list.paraphrase: Some commentators have argued that requiring adequate attribution before exercising self-defence is 'a luxury unavailable in the cyber attack era', a position the authors reject.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Captures a proposed pragmatic shift to lower attribution standards in emergency contexts; authors deem such proposals legally untenable. Important for RQs about normative proposals to relax rules.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 1. Introduction + ## 2. Cyber Security and the Military Paradigm: Self-Defence
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: There is widespread agreement that international law as it currently stands applies in cyberspace, and it is beyond any doubt that international law requires attribution.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The authors state there is broad consensus that existing international law governs cyberspace and continues to require attribution for responsibility.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Establishes the legal baseline that attribution remains a required element under current international law; helpful to reject claims that law should be suspended in cyberspace. 'Widespread agreement' is asserted rather than evidenced here.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 1. Introduction + ## 2. Cyber Security and the Military Paradigm: Self-Defence
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: will, in at least the majority of cases, effectively prevent the legal possibility of reaction with military means.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The authors contend that, in most cases, evidentiary and technical difficulties will prevent lawful military responses to cyber attacks.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Concluding synthesis: elevated evidentiary standards plus technical attribution limits make military self-defence legally infeasible in most cyber incidents. This is an interpretive policy conclusion rather than quantified empirical finding.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 1. Introduction + ## 2. Cyber Security and the Military Paradigm: Self-Defence
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: According to Article 22 of the ILC Articles on State Responsibility, ‘[t]he wrongfulness of an act of a State not in conformity with an international obligation towards another State is precluded if and to the extent that the act constitutes a countermeasure taken against the latter State'.
evidence_list.paraphrase: ILC Article 22 provides that an act which would otherwise be wrongful is not wrongful if it constitutes a countermeasure.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This is the ILC formulation that legally frames countermeasures as a circumstance precluding wrongfulness; it is authoritative for doctrinal analysis but is not itself a treaty obligation. Use this to assess whether a given cyber response can be pleaded as lawful countermeasures (which presumes other preconditions are met).
evidence_list.section_key: ## 3. Beyond the Military Paradigm: Countermeasures and Necessity
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: Countermeasures may be defined as 'pacific unilateral reactions which are intrinsically unlawful, which are adopted by one or more States against another State, when the former considers that the latter has committed an internationally wrongful act which could justify such a reaction'.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Countermeasures are described as pacific, unilateral responses that are intrinsically unlawful but can be taken when a State believes another has committed an internationally wrongful act.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This definitional formulation highlights the paradoxical nature of countermeasures (unlawful acts that can be excused). It is useful when coding legal doctrine but does not by itself set evidentiary or proportionality thresholds.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 3. Beyond the Military Paradigm: Countermeasures and Necessity
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: At the same time countermeasures are a means of triggering the responsibility of the adversary State.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Countermeasures serve to trigger the alleged responsible State's international responsibility.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This underscores the enforcement/Instrumental character of countermeasures (aiming at compliance and responsibility) rather than pure retaliation. It implies that proving responsibility is part of the legal logic of countermeasures.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 3. Beyond the Military Paradigm: Countermeasures and Necessity
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: For countermeasures to be considered lawful, Article 49(1) of the ILC Articles stipulates that the 'injured State may only take countermeasures against a State which is responsible for an internationally wrongful act in order to induce that State to comply with its obligations'.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Article 49(1) requires that countermeasures be taken only against a State responsible for an internationally wrongful act and only to induce compliance with obligations.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This legally ties the permissibility of countermeasures to (a) attribution/responsibility and (b) the remedial aim of inducing compliance. For cyber scenarios this creates a threshold problem: the victim must establish responsibility before invoking countermeasures.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 3. Beyond the Military Paradigm: Countermeasures and Necessity
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: Countermeasures may not, therefore, be employed in order to punish the adversary.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Countermeasures are not lawful if used for punishment; their purpose must be remedial (to secure compliance).
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This normative limitation distinguishes countermeasures from punitive reprisals and frames acceptable motivations for state responses. It is relevant to queries about legal aims for cyber responses.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 3. Beyond the Military Paradigm: Countermeasures and Necessity
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: Article 50 enumerates certain definite restrictions on countermeasures: they ‘shall not affect the obligation to refrain from the threat or use of force as embodied in the Charter of the United Nations; obligations for the protection of fundamental human rights; obligations of a humanitarian character prohibiting reprisals; other obligations under peremptory norms of general international law’.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Article 50 bars countermeasures from affecting obligations to refrain from force, from violating fundamental human rights, humanitarian prohibitions on reprisals, and peremptory norms.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This is a catalog of hard limits on any countermeasure (including cyber measures). It directly bears on whether particular active cyber responses would be lawful (e.g., if they impair human rights or implicate force).
evidence_list.section_key: ## 3. Beyond the Military Paradigm: Countermeasures and Necessity
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: the possibility of lawful countermeasures employing the use of force cannot be found in State practice in the Charter era since 1945
evidence_list.paraphrase: Author asserts that state practice since 1945 does not support countermeasures that lawfully employ force.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This appeal to state practice indicates a customary-law gap for forcible countermeasures; if correct, it limits arguments that cyber countermeasures may lawfully include forceful actions. Verify against broader practice evidence when synthesizing.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 3. Beyond the Military Paradigm: Countermeasures and Necessity
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: According to Article 51 of the ILC Articles on State Responsibility, which is considered to reflect customary international law, countermeasures must also be in line with the principle of proportionality or, in the provision’s wording, ‘commensurate with the injury suffered, taking into account the gravity of the internationally wrongful act and the rights in question’.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Article 51 requires countermeasures to be proportionate—commensurate with the injury, considering the gravity of the wrongful act and the rights affected.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Establishes proportionality as a substantive constraint applicable to cyber countermeasures; importantly, the passage emphasises qualitative factors, not only quantitative measures, which matters when critical infrastructure is implicated.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 3. Beyond the Military Paradigm: Countermeasures and Necessity
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: Before starting to take countermeasures an injured State must, according to the first paragraph, ‘call upon the responsible State [...] to fulfil its obligations under Part Two'.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Article 52 requires the injured State to first call on the responsible State to fulfil its obligations before taking countermeasures.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This procedural precondition (notice/request) conditions lawful countermeasure use and is pertinent to questions about required diplomatic steps prior to cyber countermeasures. The bracketed ellipsis is the original text's omission marker.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 3. Beyond the Military Paradigm: Countermeasures and Necessity
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: In cases of urgency, however, the injured State may take those measures that are ‘necessary to preserve its rights', an exception to the abovementioned paragraph 1(b) as stipulated by paragraph 2 of the same Article.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Article 52(2) permits urgent countermeasures necessary to preserve rights, creating a procedural exception to prior notification.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Useful for analyzing rapid cyber responses; but the text (and the chapter's analysis) stresses this is a procedural relief, not carte blanche. The scope of 'necessary to preserve its rights' will be contested in practice.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 3. Beyond the Military Paradigm: Countermeasures and Necessity
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: Thus, what is altered in situations of urgency is only a procedural requirement, not the evidentiary standard required to be able to resort to this remedy in the first place.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Urgency removes only certain procedural duties (e.g. prior notification); it does not relax the evidentiary standard for lawful countermeasures.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Author's interpretive claim is pivotal: urgent cyber measures still require the same proof of responsibility/attribution. This qualifies any argument that urgency obviates attribution burdens.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 3. Beyond the Military Paradigm: Countermeasures and Necessity
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: 'active defences' which, as opposed to 'passive defences' are: proactive measure[s] for detecting or obtaining information as to a cyber-intrusion, cyber-attack, or impending cyber operation, or for determining the origin of an operation that involves launching a pre-emptive, preventive, or cyber-counter operation against the source.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Active defences are proactive measures designed to detect, attribute, or launch pre-emptive/counter operations against an attack's source.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Technical/legal definition that frames active cyber responses; relevant to RQs on lawful forms of counteraction because such measures are intrusive and implicate attribution, proportionality, and third-party effects.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 3. Beyond the Military Paradigm: Countermeasures and Necessity
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: ‘in-kind response[s] [...] against the attacker’s system' in order to offensively 'disable the source of an attack'.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Active defences can take the form of in-kind responses against the attacker's systems intended to disable the attack source.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This characterisation explains why active defences raise distinctive legal problems (damage to third parties, reversibility, proportionality). It shows the operational nature of countermeasures in cyber space.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 3. Beyond the Military Paradigm: Countermeasures and Necessity
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: The main problem with countermeasures is that, as with self-defence, the remedy is dependent on the attribution of wrongful conduct;
evidence_list.paraphrase: A fundamental difficulty is that countermeasures, like self-defence, depend on attributing wrongful conduct to a State.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Direct statement linking the legality of countermeasures to attribution—central to any RQ about whether countermeasures avoid attribution challenges in cyber incidents. This shifts focus to evidentiary feasibility.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 3. Beyond the Military Paradigm: Countermeasures and Necessity
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: If attribution in order to establish State responsibility of the alleged attacker State is again a precondition, it follows that the same evidentiary standard applies as outlined above.
evidence_list.paraphrase: If attribution is required for countermeasures, the same evidentiary standard used for other legal bases (e.g., self-defence) applies to countermeasures.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Author argues countermeasures do not relax proof burdens; this is a critical interpretive claim for RQs about whether countermeasures can practically circumvent attribution problems.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 3. Beyond the Military Paradigm: Countermeasures and Necessity
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: A State ... needs to be able to show two things with clear and convincing evidence: that the attack emanated from the territory of the accused State, and that the State failed in its due diligence obligations under the duty to prevent the attack.
evidence_list.paraphrase: To justify countermeasures based on a failure to prevent, a victim State must show by clear and convincing evidence both territorial origin and a breach of due diligence.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This specifies the high evidentiary bar (clear and convincing) and the two-element test (territory + failure to prevent), making the practical use of countermeasures in cyber contexts difficult. Use this when assessing legal thresholds for non-forcible responses.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 3. Beyond the Military Paradigm: Countermeasures and Necessity
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: 'there is still no “silver bullet” in the hunt for the attackers'.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Technical experts concede there is no single reliable technical method to identify cyber attackers conclusively.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Concise technical limitation that undermines the feasibility of meeting the clear-and-convincing evidentiary standard in many cyber cases; supports sceptical treatment of attribution claims based solely on technical traces.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 3. Beyond the Military Paradigm: Countermeasures and Necessity
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: for political purposes, this sort of attribution may be sufficient, but the same can hardly be said in establishing legal responsibility as long as clear and convincing technical evidence is absent.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Political/all-source attribution may be acceptable politically, but without clear technical evidence it generally will not establish legal responsibility.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Distinguishes political attribution from the higher standards required for legal responsibility; important for RQs comparing state practice of public attribution versus legal admissibility in international fora.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 3. Beyond the Military Paradigm: Countermeasures and Necessity
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: 'definitely attributing' cyber incidents and violations of international law related thereto is still one of the 'greatest strategic challenges regarding cyber threats'.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Definitive legal attribution of cyber incidents remains one of the greatest strategic challenges in cyber security.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Reinforces that attribution is both a technical and strategic problem, not merely evidentiary; directly relevant to RQs about feasibility of legal countermeasures and remedies in cyberspace.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 3. Beyond the Military Paradigm: Countermeasures and Necessity
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: [n]ecessity may not be invoked by a State as a ground for precluding the wrongfulness of an act not in conformity with an international obligation of that State unless the act is the only way for the State to safeguard an essential interest against a grave and imminent peril
evidence_list.paraphrase: Article 25 permits necessity only when the act is the only way to safeguard an essential interest against a grave and imminent peril.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This is the central textual constraint of the necessity doctrine: it bypasses attribution but sets a strict 'only way' and 'grave and imminent' test, making necessity a narrow and exceptional justification for cyber measures.
evidence_list.section_key: ## 3. Beyond the Military Paradigm: Countermeasures and Necessity
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: 'the obligation to [prevent] is an obligation to act with due diligence in respect of all activities which take place under the jurisdiction and control of each party'.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The ICJ holds that the obligation to prevent requires states to act with due diligence regarding activities under their jurisdiction and control.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This is a leading judicial formulation tying prevention duties to jurisdiction/control and framing due diligence as conduct-based. It provides a legal baseline for arguing States must exercise control over cyber activity originating from their territory, but it does not specify cyber‑specific measures or thresholds.
evidence_list.section_key: # 4. In Search of a More Comprehensive Approach: Spelling Out States' Due Diligence Obligations in Cyberspace + # 5. Conclusion
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: It is an obligation of conduct, not of result.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Due diligence is an obligation about the conduct states must take, not an obligation to achieve a particular outcome.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This definitional point limits expectations for absolute prevention in cyberspace—states are judged on steps taken, not guaranteed outcomes. It matters for RQs on feasible state duties given technical limits in attribution and defense.
evidence_list.section_key: # 4. In Search of a More Comprehensive Approach: Spelling Out States' Due Diligence Obligations in Cyberspace + # 5. Conclusion
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: Such standard is necessarily dependant on the context and must therefore be determined for every subject matter specifically, or may even change over time 'in light [...] of new scientific or technological knowledge'
evidence_list.paraphrase: ITLOS stated that due‑diligence standards depend on context and may change with new scientific or technological knowledge.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This advisory authority supports a flexible, evolving test for due diligence — relevant to cyber where technology and knowledge evolve rapidly. It justifies adapting standards rather than fixed rules, but leaves open precise cyber thresholds.
evidence_list.section_key: # 4. In Search of a More Comprehensive Approach: Spelling Out States' Due Diligence Obligations in Cyberspace + # 5. Conclusion
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: Due diligence is generally understood to require conduct that would be adopted by any reasonable State under the given circumstances.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Due diligence is assessed by reference to what a reasonable State would do under the circumstances.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This invokes a reasonableness standard for assessing state conduct in cyber incidents. Operationalizing what a 'reasonable State' would do in technical cyber contexts remains a major evidentiary and normative challenge.
evidence_list.section_key: # 4. In Search of a More Comprehensive Approach: Spelling Out States' Due Diligence Obligations in Cyberspace + # 5. Conclusion
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: required signatory States to undertake measures of prevention by establishing ‘criminal offences for almost every conceivable type of cyber-attack under their domestic laws'.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The Convention on Cybercrime obliges signatories to adopt domestic criminal offences covering most types of cyber‑attack.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Treaty practice shows states have legislated broadly against cyber misconduct, supporting the argument that criminalisation can be part of preventive due diligence; heterogeneity in membership and enforcement limits universality.
evidence_list.section_key: # 4. In Search of a More Comprehensive Approach: Spelling Out States' Due Diligence Obligations in Cyberspace + # 5. Conclusion
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: Thus, it may be argued that the due diligence standard at least amounts to the obligation to enact laws that criminalise cyber attacks, and to prosecute the perpetrators when an attack has occurred.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The author contends that due diligence minimally requires states to criminalise cyber attacks and to prosecute offenders.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This is an interpretive claim linking due diligence to legislative and prosecutorial duties; persuasive given treaty and UN practice but contingent on acceptance of analogies between cyber and other transboundary harms.
evidence_list.section_key: # 4. In Search of a More Comprehensive Approach: Spelling Out States' Due Diligence Obligations in Cyberspace + # 5. Conclusion
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: '[a] State shall not knowingly allow the cyber infrastructure located in its territory or under its exclusive governmental control to be used for acts that adversely and unlawfully affect other States'.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The Tallinn Manual states a State must not knowingly permit cyber infrastructure under its control to be used to unlawfully harm other States.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: As influential soft law, the Tallinn Manual expresses a non‑allowance norm and a control-based duty; useful as interpretive guidance for due diligence and attribution debates despite lacking binding force.
evidence_list.section_key: # 4. In Search of a More Comprehensive Approach: Spelling Out States' Due Diligence Obligations in Cyberspace + # 5. Conclusion
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: is an obligation which entails not only the adoption of appropriate rules and measures, but also a certain level of vigilance in their enforcement and the exercise of administrative control applicable to public and private operators
evidence_list.paraphrase: The ICJ held that due diligence requires adopting rules and exercising vigilance in enforcement, including administrative control over public and private operators.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This formulation explicitly contemplates monitoring and enforcement as elements of due diligence — particularly relevant in cyber where private infrastructure is central. It raises proportionality and human‑rights concerns when applied to network surveillance.
evidence_list.section_key: # 4. In Search of a More Comprehensive Approach: Spelling Out States' Due Diligence Obligations in Cyberspace + # 5. Conclusion
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: could not agree whether such a preventative duty exists as regards cyber attacks due to the inherent ‘difficulty of mounting comprehensive and effective defences against all possible threats'.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The Tallinn Group of Experts could not agree that a preventative duty exists because mounting comprehensive defenses against all cyber threats is inherently difficult.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Expert disagreement highlights practical limits to imposing broad prevention duties in cyberspace; this undermines easy transposition of classic due‑diligence duties to the cyber environment.
evidence_list.section_key: # 4. In Search of a More Comprehensive Approach: Spelling Out States' Due Diligence Obligations in Cyberspace + # 5. Conclusion
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: the due diligence standard would not impose an absolute obligation to avoid all attacks and there might thus still be cases – especially when continuous and/or similar attack patterns are at issue – where the State ‘should have known’ of malicious conduct within the networks on its own territory.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The text argues due diligence is not absolute and that persistent or similar attack patterns may create a 'should have known' standard for states regarding malicious activity on their networks.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This introduces a constructive‑knowledge test that can ground state responsibility in cyber contexts when attack patterns are continuous; operationalizing 'should have known' will be fact‑specific and technically demanding.
evidence_list.section_key: # 4. In Search of a More Comprehensive Approach: Spelling Out States' Due Diligence Obligations in Cyberspace + # 5. Conclusion
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: In its Corfu Channel decision, the ICJ considered such constructive knowledge sufficient for a due diligence violation under certain factual conditions.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The ICJ's Corfu Channel decision treated constructive knowledge as sufficient for a due‑diligence violation in particular factual circumstances.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Corfu Channel provides judicial precedent for constructive knowledge in state responsibility claims; however, the factual matrix there (physical waterways) differs from cyber, limiting direct transposition.
evidence_list.section_key: # 4. In Search of a More Comprehensive Approach: Spelling Out States' Due Diligence Obligations in Cyberspace + # 5. Conclusion
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: any potential due diligence obligation would have to be in line with international human rights obligations and not be used as a pretext for censorship and surveillance
evidence_list.paraphrase: Any cyber due‑diligence obligations must comply with international human‑rights obligations and must not be used to justify censorship or intrusive surveillance.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This is an explicit normative constraint: security duties must be balanced against rights protections. It is crucial when assessing proposals that involve monitoring, mandatory reporting or compelled disclosure.
evidence_list.section_key: # 4. In Search of a More Comprehensive Approach: Spelling Out States' Due Diligence Obligations in Cyberspace + # 5. Conclusion
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: multilateral communication about possible technical failures and security-relevant shortcomings as well as other minor cyber incidents (especially when due to zero-day exploits) should be permanent and mandatory, in order to enable all States to prepare for possible attacks or security breaches.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The author argues multilateral, mandatory communication about technical failures and minor incidents (including zero‑days) should be continuous so states can prepare for attacks.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Proposes a permanent, mandatory information‑sharing regime to improve preparedness. Politically and commercially sensitive issues (disclosure risks, liability, costs) complicate implementation but the proposal addresses attribution limits by focusing on prevention and readiness.
evidence_list.section_key: # 4. In Search of a More Comprehensive Approach: Spelling Out States' Due Diligence Obligations in Cyberspace + # 5. Conclusion
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: the standard implies obligations to cooperate with the victim State in order to prevent further harm or to mitigate the consequences of an incident.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The standard implies an obligation to cooperate with a victim state to prevent further harm or mitigate consequences after a cyber incident.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Draws on analogies to transboundary cooperation in other fields (health, hazardous activities) to justify post‑incident cooperation duties; operational scope (forensics, assistance, evidence sharing) requires specification.
evidence_list.section_key: # 4. In Search of a More Comprehensive Approach: Spelling Out States' Due Diligence Obligations in Cyberspace + # 5. Conclusion
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: In a domain where attribution of conduct is inherently difficult if not impossible, a much stronger focus should be placed on the preventive dimension than the repressive dimension.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Because attribution is often very difficult or impossible in cyberspace, the author argues prevention should be prioritized over repressive responses.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This links attribution limits to policy choice: prioritise prevention/resilience rather than military or punitive measures. Central for RQs about how attribution difficulties should shape legal and policy responses.
evidence_list.section_key: # 4. In Search of a More Comprehensive Approach: Spelling Out States' Due Diligence Obligations in Cyberspace + # 5. Conclusion
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: To date no cyber security incident has actually risen to the level of an armed attack.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The author asserts that, so far, no cyber incident has met the legal threshold of an armed attack.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: This empirical/legal baseline limits resort to self‑defence in cyberspace as of the time of writing; it is time‑sensitive and may change as incidents evolve or as legal interpretations shift.
evidence_list.section_key: # 4. In Search of a More Comprehensive Approach: Spelling Out States' Due Diligence Obligations in Cyberspace + # 5. Conclusion
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: due to the persisting attribution problem and the myriad uncertainties surrounding tracing the origin of an attack in cyberspace, in most instances it will be legally untenable.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The author argues that persistent attribution problems and uncertainties about tracing attack origins generally make forceful legal responses legally untenable.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Stresses the causal link between attribution capacity and legality of measures like self‑defence; directly relevant to RQs on evidentiary standards required for inter‑State responses in cyber incidents.
evidence_list.section_key: # 4. In Search of a More Comprehensive Approach: Spelling Out States' Due Diligence Obligations in Cyberspace + # 5. Conclusion
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: Some of these problems can be solved; others could at least be mitigated if non-forcible unilateral responses to cyber incidents of unclear origin that affect other State's interest could be better coordinated and ultimately institutionalised on the basis of an international treaty.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The author suggests that coordinating and institutionalising non‑forcible unilateral responses via an international treaty could solve or mitigate some problems.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Policy recommendation to shift from ad‑hoc unilateral responses toward treaty‑based coordination of non‑forcible measures; politically ambitious and would require agreement on definitions, verification and compliance mechanisms.
evidence_list.section_key: # 4. In Search of a More Comprehensive Approach: Spelling Out States' Due Diligence Obligations in Cyberspace + # 5. Conclusion
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: Certainly, in the long run a cogent path would be a much stronger focus on specifying States' due diligence obligations regarding threat prevention and securing the freedom and stability of cyberspace.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The chapter concludes that, in the long run, specifying States' due‑diligence obligations for threat prevention and cyber stability is the preferred path.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: Summative normative claim directing law‑making and institutional reform toward clearer due‑diligence rules; useful as a research/policy agenda item though political feasibility and technical details remain unresolved.
evidence_list.section_key: # 4. In Search of a More Comprehensive Approach: Spelling Out States' Due Diligence Obligations in Cyberspace + # 5. Conclusion
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: As a consequence of the advent of transnational terrorism, the UN main bodies have adopted resolutions that can be read as catalogues of due diligence obligations to combat the threat, most significantly urging States to criminalise and prosecute terrorist acts, to cooperate to this end and more generally to exchange crucial information and not to (consciously) let their own territory become a launching base for terrorist attacks.
evidence_list.paraphrase: UN organs have adopted resolutions that enumerate due‑diligence duties — criminalisation, prosecution, cooperation, information‑sharing, and preventing territory being used for attacks — in response to transnational terrorism.
evidence_list.researcher_comment: The author uses post‑terrorism UN practice as an analogue to suggest similar due‑diligence norms could emerge for cyber; analogical reasoning is persuasive but must account for technical and sovereignty differences between terrorism and cyber threats.
evidence_list.section_key: # 4. In Search of a More Comprehensive Approach: Spelling Out States' Due Diligence Obligations in Cyberspace + # 5. Conclusion
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: This chapter argues that, while self-defence certainly cannot be ruled out, the problem of attribution will preclude its proper application in many, if not most, instances.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The chapter contends that although self-defence remains possible, attribution problems will prevent its proper application in many, if not most, cases.
evidence_list.section_key: __intro_conclusion_harvest__
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: the greatest challenge for the application of the doctrine of self-defence to the new threats that arrive as a by-product of technological developments is the attribution of ‘unlawful conduct’.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The author identifies attribution of 'unlawful conduct' as the principal obstacle to applying the self-defence doctrine to emerging cyber threats.
evidence_list.section_key: __intro_conclusion_harvest__
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: In 1987, the Iran-United States Claims Tribunal asserted that ‘[i]n order to attribute an act to the State, it is necessary to identify with reasonable certainty the actors and their association with the State’.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The Tribunal held that state attribution requires identifying with reasonable certainty both the actors and their association with the State.
evidence_list.section_key: __intro_conclusion_harvest__
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: Those are: the *prima facie* possibility of an asserted fact being true; a preponderance of evidence; the ‘clear and convincing’ evidentiary standard; and proof beyond reasonable doubt.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The author lists four formal evidentiary standards used in international adjudication: prima facie, preponderance, clear and convincing, and proof beyond reasonable doubt.
evidence_list.section_key: __intro_conclusion_harvest__
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: as soon as State responsibility is involved the required threshold appears to be considerably higher, shifting towards ‘clear and convincing’.
evidence_list.paraphrase: When State responsibility is at issue, the evidentiary threshold increases and tends toward a 'clear and convincing' standard.
evidence_list.section_key: __intro_conclusion_harvest__
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: This standard essentially amounts to the duty to ‘convince the arbiter in question that it is substantially more likely than not that the factual claims that have been made are true.’
evidence_list.paraphrase: The 'clear and convincing' standard requires persuading the adjudicator that the asserted facts are substantially more likely than not to be true.
evidence_list.section_key: __intro_conclusion_harvest__
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: ‘the determination of the identity or location of an attacker or an attacker’s intermediary’ remains the most critical and to date unresolved obstacle to the application of the traditional regime of self-defence in the context of cyberspace.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Determining an attacker’s identity or location remains the single most critical unresolved obstacle to applying traditional self-defence in cyberspace.
evidence_list.section_key: __intro_conclusion_harvest__
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: The current architecture of the internet and connected networks provides countless loopholes and methods to mask a user’s identity or location.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The internet’s architecture contains numerous loopholes enabling the masking of user identities or locations, which hinders reliable attribution.
evidence_list.section_key: __intro_conclusion_harvest__
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: the location of a computer rarely allows for definite conclusions regarding the identity of the individual operating the machine
evidence_list.paraphrase: Knowing a computer’s location rarely permits definite conclusions about who operated it, complicating legal attribution.
evidence_list.section_key: __intro_conclusion_harvest__
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: However, so far even the most publicly endorsed instances of ‘smoking gun’ evidence regarding malicious cyber conduct have been met with reservations and objections by high-profile cyber security analysts.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Even widely publicised 'smoking gun' technical evidence of malicious cyber activity has been questioned by experts, reducing confidence in attribution claims.
evidence_list.section_key: __intro_conclusion_harvest__
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: it took their analysts several years to come up with conclusions that they themselves considered sufficiently convincing to be published.
evidence_list.paraphrase: High-profile forensic attributions (e.g., Mandiant) have required analysts several years to reach publishable conclusions, creating timeliness problems for responses.
evidence_list.section_key: __intro_conclusion_harvest__
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: The recently completed Tallinn Manual on the International Law Applicable to Cyber Warfare (Tallinn Manual), points to the requirement of immediacy for self-defence to be permitted, meaning the period of time 'following the execution of an armed attack within which the victim State may reasonably respond in self-defence', with one relevant factor inter alia being 'the period necessary to identify the attacker'.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The Tallinn Manual treats immediacy as a necessary condition for lawful self-defence and expressly counts the time required to identify the attacker as a relevant factor.
evidence_list.section_key: __intro_conclusion_harvest__
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: In cases where 'the initiator of the attack is not identified until well after the attack' the criterion of immediacy will usually not be met.
evidence_list.paraphrase: If the initiator is identified only long after an incident, the immediacy requirement for self-defence will typically fail to be satisfied.
evidence_list.section_key: __intro_conclusion_harvest__
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: Hence, the community of States should continue to demand a more stringent temporal proximity between an armed attack and its response invoking self-defence.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The author urges States to insist on stricter temporal proximity between an armed attack and any self-defence response.
evidence_list.section_key: __intro_conclusion_harvest__
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: The suggestion that the standards of attribution should shift from 'effective control' to 'overall control' does not touch upon the issue of identification.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Proposals to replace an 'effective control' test with an 'overall control' test do not address the central factual problem of identifying who carried out a cyber operation.
evidence_list.section_key: __intro_conclusion_harvest__
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: Deliberations that aim to lower the evidentiary standard regarding cyberspace issues, emphasising the ex-ante perspective of decision-makers in emergency situations, or even bluntly asserting that the requirement of adequate attribution of an attack before resorting to self-defence measures is 'a luxury unavailable in the cyber attack era', can hardly be considered legally tenable.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The author rejects proposals to lower evidentiary standards in cyber cases or to treat attribution as an unaffordable 'luxury' as legally untenable.
evidence_list.section_key: __intro_conclusion_harvest__
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: There is widespread agreement that international law as it currently stands applies in cyberspace, and it is beyond any doubt that international law requires attribution.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The chapter asserts that existing international law governs cyberspace and continues to require attribution before assigning State responsibility.
evidence_list.section_key: __intro_conclusion_harvest__
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: Finally, suggesting a reversal of the burden of proof could easily lead to wrong and even absurd results given the possibility of routing cyber operations through numerous countries, and to the denouncing of wholly uninvolved and innocent States.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The author warns that reversing the burden of proof could produce absurd results because cyber operations can be routed through many States, implicating innocent parties.
evidence_list.section_key: __intro_conclusion_harvest__
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: the standard of proof required by international law when making claims that involve another State’s responsibility (especially for an armed attack) in combination with the technical peculiarities of cyberspace will, in at least the majority of cases, effectively prevent the legal possibility of reaction with military means.
evidence_list.paraphrase: High evidentiary requirements plus cyberspace's technical peculiarities mean that in most cases legal proof will preclude lawful military responses to cyber incidents.
evidence_list.section_key: __intro_conclusion_harvest__
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: What is needed at least in the midterm is a more comprehensive approach that complements those remedies, providing a legal framework that spells out the duties of States concerning cyber security more concretely.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The author recommends developing a midterm comprehensive legal framework that complements unilateral remedies and concretely specifies States' cyber-security duties.
evidence_list.section_key: __intro_conclusion_harvest__
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: due diligence serves as the standard for any international duties to prevent certain events from occurring. It is an obligation of conduct, not of result.
evidence_list.paraphrase: Due diligence is presented as the international prevention standard, imposing obligations of conduct rather than guaranteeing particular outcomes.
evidence_list.section_key: __intro_conclusion_harvest__
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: Thus, it may be argued that the due diligence standard at least amounts to the obligation to enact laws that criminalise cyber attacks, and to prosecute the perpetrators when an attack has occurred.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The chapter argues that due diligence should at minimum require States to criminalise cyber attacks domestically and prosecute perpetrators.
evidence_list.section_key: __intro_conclusion_harvest__
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: the Tallinn Manual asserts that '[a] State shall not knowingly allow the cyber infrastructure located in its territory or under its exclusive governmental control to be used for acts that adversely and unlawfully affect other States'.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The Tallinn Manual states that a State must not knowingly permit cyber infrastructure under its control to be used to harm other States.
evidence_list.section_key: __intro_conclusion_harvest__
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: due diligence is an obligation which entails not only the adoption of appropriate rules and measures, but also a certain level of vigilance in their enforcement and the exercise of administrative control applicable to public and private operators, such as the monitoring of activities undertaken by such operators, to safeguard the rights of the other party.
evidence_list.paraphrase: The ICJ-framed due diligence duty requires not just rules but active vigilance and enforcement, including monitoring by public and private operators to protect other States' rights.
evidence_list.section_key: __intro_conclusion_harvest__
evidence_list.pdf_path: /mnt/c/Users/luano/Zotero/storage/34RLRYKB/Geiss and Lahmann - 2014 - Freedom and security in cyberspace shifting the focus away from military responses towards non-forc.pdf

evidence_list.quote: it appears reasonable to assert that multilateral communication about possible technical failures and security-relevant shortcomings as well as other minor cyber incidents (especially when due to zero-day exploits) should be permanent and mandatory, in order to enable all States to prepare for possible attacks or security breaches.
